posts.name: Viraj
posts.cooked:
Url: https://api.github.com/search/users?q=location:Austin+followers:>100
It says total count: 471. >100 at end ensures I look for users in Austin with more than 100 followers since the instructions state “over 100” followers.
Am I right in understanding that my users.csv should contain data for 471 unique login ids? So 472 rows including title row.
I am asking because I get wrong answers for questions 11-15 and I am unable to figure out why. Since repositories.csv depends on users.csv to be created, I need the clarification.

posts.name: Sid
posts.cooked:
Yes to all the questions above.
You may be getting incorrect answers for various other reasons like format, spaces, boolean values etc. Refer other posts for clarifications

posts.name: Jivraj Singh Shekhawat
posts.cooked: Yes there needs to be 472 rows for your dataset(1 row for title + 471 unique users login’s)

posts.name: Viraj
posts.cooked:
@ 22f3003031
Aren’t most of the fields very dynamic?
For example this particular user: https://api.github.com/users/benawad

Yesterday when I scraped benawad had 29015 followers. Today when I scraped again he had 29014 followers. Won’t this affect the answers?
Forgive me if the questions are naïve, I am not from programming background.

posts.name: Jivraj Singh Shekhawat
posts.cooked:
Yes, some fields are dynamic but, answers won’t change, Because Backend script is calculating answers from files that you upload on GitHub.

Answer questions based on data uploaded on github.

posts.name: Viraj
posts.cooked:
Jivraj:

Answer questions based on data uploaded on github.

Thank you for the clarification. I was not updating files on github before updating answers.
But then I can make errors in fetching data (wrongly handling boolean, symbols, null) but go on to employ correct method to answer questions and hence get answers marked as correct?

posts.name: Bahni Roy
posts.cooked:
That should not have been the case.
My repository file is ~2.5MB and contains close to 30k records.

Further, your users file appears to be about 5 -6 times the size it should have been.

Can you review the user details query and see if the applicable filters are present (as mentioned in the project description)? Review the count of the distinct loginids.

A 51MB repositories file indicate that way too many users have been fetched in the initial query (because the repositories result set is based off of that number).

posts.name: Amit Kumar Gupta
posts.cooked: Figured it out, script captured lot more columns than required, now its fixed, 2.5 mb is correct
